newsitem.title: USA: Borland shares rise after surprise slim profit.
newsitem.headline: Borland shares rise after surprise slim profit.

text.p: Borland International Inc. stock jumped Wednesday, a day after the software tools maker startled Wall Street with a narrow first-quarter profit showing signs that its turnaround was taking shape.
"We think we bottomed out in the third quarter," Borland Chief Executive Officer Delbert Yocam, who took the helm of the company last December, said in an interview.

On Tuesday, the company reported a net profit of $79,000 for its first fiscal quarter ended on June 30, compared with a net loss of $21.8 million a year earlier. Sales rose 10 percent to $41.9 million.

The result was break-even in terms of earnings per share, but it was well above Zacks Investment Research's Wall Street consensus estimate of a loss of 19 cents a share. Borland stock rose 62.5 cents to $7.31 in active trading on Nasdaq.

"We obviously want to continue to improve on both the top line and the bottom line each and every quarter during this turnaround," said Yocam, who declined to comment on details of the company's upcoming quarterly financial objectives.
Borland said in April it expected to be profitable in fiscal 1998 after taking more than $23 million in charges for a global restructuring and other one-time expenses.
The restructuring involved a 30 percent work force reduction. Borland's operating expenses fell by a third to $35.5 million in the latest quarter from $53.5 million a year earlier.

Yocam's strategy includes providing greater stability for sales of Borland tools -- which are used by developers to make computer programmes -- by producing either a new product or a major upgrade of an existing product each quarter.
In a research report, UBS Securities analysts said they raised their earnings estimates for the fiscal year ending in March 1998 to 10 cents a share from 1 cent a share.
"The management team has moved swiftly in getting costs under control," the report said. "We think the stock should finally start to move up here."
Borland, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., reported a $29.4 million loss in its third quarter ended last December.
